urlLink This here is a wonderfully funny article in the Wall Street Journal ostensibly about one item in particular -- TiVo -- and its pattern recognition habits. If you care to look at this article a little more closely, you'll find that it's actually about artificial intelligence and consumer profiling. Simply put, I don't want people to know what I purchase: it's no one's business but my own. I don't care who you are or where you work, the fact that I'm taking home 15 boxes of Oreo cookies affects no one but me. Right now there's a lot of data mining going on. Air Miles was one of the first and probably the most well known, but Safeway and, more recently, Shoppers Drug Mart have also stuck their noses in. And it's this leveraging of information under the guise of consumer benefit that has me concerned. Sure, these organizations do throw you a bone for allowing them to rape your private life: one reward mile for every $20 spent, twenty cents off fishsticks, etc. And don't forget what a big favour they're doing for you by being able to personalize your advertising! No more need for us carnivores to see those annoying veggie-burger ads. The facts are that Air Miles et al are making ridiculous amount of money tracking spending habits and releasing this data to third parties. Advertisers want to get more bang for their buck by targeting ads and really couldn't care less about consumer benefit, although they do use it as a smoke screen. And I really hate to do this, but it's only a matter of time until someone, somewhere, starts looking for correlations in spending and purchases to see if you've been planning something naughty... how many false alarms is this going to bring down each year? You mean I'm being questioned over the styrofoam cups I bought in December and the fertilizer I bought in April? Ridiculous! Look advertisers. If you want my personal information, ask me for it. I'm more than happy to cooperate. In fact, I enjoy filling out surveys and giving companies feedback. Furthermore, I hold companies that do this in higher regard than those that go sneaking around behind my back, gathering data the way dogs dig through garbage. Spend less money on advertising and more on making good products! I promise you, if the product is good it will sell itself.

You know, last night I read an urlLink interesting article in Wired news, about the effects, if any, of prayer on the physically ill. It's well written and a good read, but most fetching was this paragraph: The time for miracles had run out on Elisabeth Targ. It was a scary moment for the uninitiated, her lungs suddenly gasping for air, trying to hang on, hyperventilating, nearly barking, spasming for more than half an hour. But this literal last gasp is how most die, and Comings knew this, so as he held her in his arms he felt relieved that she would soon be free of the illusion that is this world. This is how my grandma died: a shell, empty inside, gasping for breath not through some desire for life, but because of an uncaring biological imperative. It was disgusting to see this woman who once spoke and laughed and loved reduced to this hollow automation. Thankfully, as in the article, it didn't last. How hard this must have been on Elisabeth's husband as he held her in extremis, torn between having it all mercifully over, and never, ever letting her go. And the worst part of all is that the article says, "But this literal last gasp is how most die." I'm sure it's true, but I don't want to believe that life is really so cruel. There's a right to die rant in there somewhere, but I'm going to let it lie. This time.

Well, here it is: the first post in my blog. I suppose every blog starts out this way -- but believe me, I'm not going to be trite. With Colleen attending Westerns as SEDA's adult delegate, I was forced to take her place on the radio today. I was on CJTR 91.3, Regina Community Radio, talking about SEDA on CultureJam. Colleen said, "You've been here a long time, you know what the deal is. You'll be fine." And, you know, yeah, I have been here a long time, and yeah, I do know what the deal is, and yeah, I was fine. However, fine is always the bare minimum in my life. To be worthy, everything I do has to be exceptional. And although I was able to reasonably hold my own on CultureJam and fill in the general public on what SEDA is all about, there was an aspect of this that left me feeling uneasy. I wasn't able to put my finger on it until I was driving back to the office. There is a subtle art to the deflection of questions: that is, giving an answer without answering at all. Some debaters are inherently good at it, and it's one of the skills that debate develops. Colleen, as a former debater, is good at it. Deron, as a non-debater, needs practice. As a for instance: I was asked if SEDA also involves groups other than students in our programs. I responded that we don't currently have anything set up for adults who wish to debate, or other similar groups, but that being involved with students through the school system is the most effective way to reach the largest number of people with our organization's resources. That was good! Later on, I was asked how one of SEDA's debaters placed at Worlds. As I didn't have that information with me, and I had no idea, I said that I didn't know. That was bad. Better would have been that I didn't know, but that attending Worlds alone showed the amount of effort and dedication he had put into his activities. Answer without answering. I'll work on it. The important thing is that next time I will be all the better.

I'm still around, not to worry; the holiday malaise has not claimed me yet. But this will be my last post before heading home for the holidays. The reason for my absence is that I was slowly working on a story -- I have this theory about all blogs heading toward a state of prose. But as it's currently in a state of limbo I thought I'd make what might be my last post of 2002. urlLink Dr. Laura's mom died . Dr. Laura was estranged from her mother for a number of years -- he mother's choice, she says -- and her lack of a family life was one of the reasons she pushed so hard for family values. There are other ways to look at this, of course: Dr. Laura's lack of a traditional family unit didn't prevent her from reaching success, such as it is. Perhaps appropriate role models and the proper spin of life's ups and downs are more important in the long run? An older, wiser confidant shapes a younger person into a responsible adult? A topic for another post, probably. But the topic of this post is that some of us get the choice to spend the holidays with our families and some of us don't. Some of us like spending the holidays with our families, and some of us don't. But it's great to be able to have that kind of choice, and it's awful when we yearn so strongly for what we once had. Yeah, I don't really savour the idea of spending the holidays with my family. But really, things are not that bad. I, like everyone, should try and keep this in perspective. Signing off of her show, Dr. Laura said: "I just want to remind you as I do all the time, hold your family very tight, very close and very dear and don't sweat the petty stuff -- the bad stuff is bad enough." Finally some good advice from the woman. Happy Holidays.

Before I forget again, I wanted to post something on God-given talents. I have an acquaintance who raps. He also happens to be a Christian fundamentalist and, oddly enough, he raps about God. This is fine -- whatever makes his bed rock and all that -- but I have to wonder what's going through his head while he raps. Does he feel God's spirit moving through him? Does feel that he's going to convert someone to Christianity through his rap? I joked with a friend one day, "You know, I've been an athiest all my life, but your rap really changed my mind." I seriously think he's waiting for this scenario to play out. I expect him to say that his rapping talent is God-given. So this got me thinking about what exactly is a God-given talent. Does rapping even qualify? If so, what about a talent like walking and chewing gum? What if I was the best there ever was at walking and chewing gum? I've logged thousands of miles walking and chewing gum, and I've never slipped, fallen, gotten out of step, spit out or swallowed my gum, or forgotten to chew. I'm just hoping that my God-given walking and gum-chewing talent will show people the light. What if I could point out physical or mental flaws with people? Is that a God-given talent? What about the ability to steal anything and not get caught? What about if I was able to kill people better than anyone who's ever lived? Would God grant someone such a dark blessing? What exactly qualifies? The answer came to me as I was stuffing envelopes, of all things. It all ends up being a matter of perspective. Walking and chewing gum may not be a God-given talent, but perhaps dexterity is. Rapping may not qualify, but maybe eloquence does. As for the darker gifts I alluded to, there may be aspects like insight, foresight, or intelligence inherent in any of those "skills" -- these are the qualities may be God-given, but it's how you use your talents that's important. And anyway, it all remains a matter of perspective: you see what you want to see. "Wow! His rap is amazing! Only God could create such an awesome ability!" or "Oh crap, here comes that rap guy again. I'm sure the devil put him here to annoy me."

I've got to start being less self-conscious about what I'm writing. Maybe this blogging thing, like all things, just comes with time. I'd like to take a moment to share a joke that I love, but no one appreciates: A man goes up to a cabbie in New York City. "How do you get to Carnegie Hall?" he asks. "Practice," says the cabbie. Today I was leafing through what I believe was the October 2002 issue of Rolling Stone. Inside they had a brief review of Kurt Cobain's diary. The review is positive overall, and they share a few tidbits about the content -- one of them being that he consistently misspells heroin as "heroine". A few things ran through my head as I read that. Firstly, I largely regard gross misspellings as a sign of intellectual weakness. But this is Cobain we're talking about -- maybe not the sharpest knife in the drawer, but certainly no idiot! My second thought was that maybe I was being too hard on the guy. But, you know, I'm not. Language is a tool for effective communication, not a method whereby you should cater to the lowest common denominator. Sure, even with the worst misspellings and punctuation, you can certainly get the gist of whatever it is someone is trying to get across. But I don't believe we should continue to settle for the least possible effort. I don't believe that we should continue to let the bar be set at adequate. I believe that we should strive to do our best, and I believe that we should attempt to use language to communicate to the best of our abilities -- if this means looking up a word or two in the dictionary that we feel we may be misspelling, so be it. I tend to be a stickler about such things. I want to write well and I want to speak well, mostly because, like everyone, I wish to be understood. I recently met someone who is as much a stickler as I am, and whenever she points out one of my mistakes I am mortified. I don't want to be branded as an idiot -- but then again, by blogging isn't there a danger of branding myself? There is a reason that Shakespeare has lasted so long, why his works resonate so well with people of different ages and backgrounds: he was able to take mere language and elevate it to an art. He was able to string words together to describe thoughts and feelings that were previously only vague terms and wild gestures. He showed us that, although it's nothing more than a system of mutually agreed on sounds, language can be beautiful. Forgive me if I respect the man and his medium. Forgive me for wanting everyone to be beautiful.

It occurs to me today -- just now -- that this blog is me. I looked into the history of Weblogs and found that a lot of them were originally social commentary or discussions and opinions on certain Websites or the state of the Web. Since they've gained popularity they've become more on-line journals than alternative news sources. I didn't want to stray too much from the original formula. I mean, I'm fairly old-school, I don't really need to keep a journal of my thoughts, and really, there's more than enough Web content out there to satisfy even the most die-hard pundit. But the problem was that this blog, like most things in my life, lacked focus and direction. I wanted to talk about issues important to me, but I wanted to look at them from a third-party perspective. And that just wasn't working. This blog is me. This blog is my life, my opinions, my commentary. It's time I took the reins. As Cameron said in urlLink Ferris Bueller's Day Off : "I am not going to sit on my ass as the events that affect me unfold to determine the course of my life." Word, homey. So I'm reading in Wired News about urlLink World AIDS Day and the Link and Think campaign . I think it's a marvellous idea. Although everyone is familiar with AIDS few stop to actually measure the social impact that the disease has. As has been said in more eloquent prose, these people are your brothers, your sisters, your parents, your friends. 42 million people is just a faceless number, but to put it in context is to clarify the awful power of this virus. Although I currently don't know anyone now who has AIDS, odds are strong that one day I will. If we want to stop the spread, education and awareness are our greatest resources. urlLink A story referenced in the article is a must read. It's well-written, heartbreaking, tragic, uplifting. A story of hope and salvation in the midst of despair. It's these kinds of stories we need to share. We need to put a human face on this monster. 42 million people . Remember.

Funny, I thought my last post was also my last post; good thing I always have things to talk about. I was at the library book sale today and I picked up a book called urlLink God Doesn't Believe in Atheists by Ray Comfort. I only got to read the first 16 pages during lunch, but it's already completely insulting to anyone who is actually searching for truth. It occurs to me that the churchies have far more to gain than the atheists and agnostics. They move under this pretense of salvation, but really they don't want to be alone, like a child in the dark. The more people they can gather to their side of the argument, the less alone they feel and the more justified their position. Why do you think they always talk to you in greater numbers? I don't remember the last time I saw a parade of atheists and agnostics handing out tracks and warning people away from their freedom of religious choice -- and yet this is the same kind of hypocrisy we deal with all the time from religious groups. Where's the non-religious or anti-religious programming on Sunday morning television? I was at home one day when the doorbell rang. Outside were two pretty young mormon women -- perhaps both looking for a husband, I couldn't say. Anyway, they asked me what religion I was, and I told them I was an agnostic. "So you don't believe in God?" the one said. "No," I replied, "I believe that the fundamental question about God's existance is unknowable. I'm sure they knew what an agnostic is, they apparently just didn't want to get into it with me -- which was a good choice on their part. The next day we found a little yellow religious tract in our mailbox telling us, essentially, that non-believers were going to hell. Again, this is an interesting tactic: if you can't strong-arm them, and you can't reason with them, scare them. I'm not trying to say that my beliefs are right for everyone, or anyone, or even myself. I've had a progression of beliefs that have lead me down the road I'm on, and I'm sure they will evolve further. But I resent people telling me that what I believe is wrong when they themselves don't know any more than I do. I resent that my freedom of belief is infringed by these religious groups. I resent that I am asked to support my beliefs when I accept theirs unquestioningly. Spend your energy converting through works and example. Spend your energy caring for the starving and homeless. Show me how the world could be, and let the people come to you.
It's days like this that I feel I'm no longer living, only prolonging my agony.
No matter how much you love someone, watching them slowly erode will destroy you.

Wired News is running a three-part series right now on the newsgroup alt.suicide holiday, or ASH, as it's known. Apparently their "pro-suicide" stance has been linked to the deaths of at least 10 people. urlLink Today's article talked specifically about a guy named Michael Benjamins, now deceased, who was a frequent poster to ASH. The series deals with the theme of suicide being a valid lifestyle choice. I read urlLink part 1 yesterday and thought about it all night. I've lived with suicidal thoughts almost half my life. When I read about Michael and what he posted to ASH, in one sense I could really relate to him. People will always tell you things will get better eventually , that life can be better with drugs and counselling. But when you haven't eaten in four days and the passing minutes are torturous in their length, and there's nothing that gives you even the smallest bit of solace or respite from the pain and lonliness, it's hard to listen to people who tell you that in a year you'll look back on this time and laugh. A year from now? I barely pulled my ass through today , and only by sleeping for twenty hours. I no longer eat out of enjoyment or hunger or even habit, but because I force myself. The only things I think about are how cruel and unjust the world really is, and why the fuck aren't I dead already. People who regularly advise drugs and counselling haven't ever really reached that place where there's only emptiness, where you are truly and completely disconnected from everything there is. You have so little desire you can't even cry about it. You can't even speak. In fact, there's nothing you can do, because there is nothing you want to do. I'm a firm believer that there are times when murder is justified. I also believe there are times when suicide is justified -- terminal illness, for example. And I've sometimes thought that there are some people who should not have been born. Some people are capable of coping better than others; some people are put off by even the smallest of life's disruptions. Maybe there are no easy answers when it comes to this subject. I think that, dispite my "illness", I have it relatively easy: I don't want to die. I've never attempted suicide, I've just often thought about how sweet a release it would be. But for me, hope does spring eternal. I have my troubles -- we all do -- but I also have my joys. And while I'd be willing to let go of some of them for a short while, in death you give up everything you've ever enjoyed. Forever. For me, it's too dear a price. But is it for everyone? Is suicide a valid lifestyle choice? Are some of the people posting to ASH on a lark, not knowing there are people taking them seriously? Do drowning men really grasp at straws? I don't know. I don't know any of these things. I don't know if I should force someone to continue living if he or she truly wants to die. All I know is that when I read Benjamins' final post on ASH, I wanted to embrace this man. For his comfort or my own, I could not say. "I want to thank all of you Ashers for being my friends in this last month. Here I was able to talk about my feelings and plans without having to fear the repercussions. I do not think I could do that in real life. I have been in a mental ward before, and I do not want to go back. "None of you really knew me as a person, other than through my posts. That's good. I kind of wanted it that way. But at the same time, I want you all to know that I am ... I WAS ... a living, breathing human being. Someone with an identity and dignity, who wanted only to be free of depression, to be loved and to feel safe. "I am Michael Benjamins. Born March 19, 1976. An artist, cat-lover, computer programmer, and thinker, who had a tendency to wear all black clothes. I tried my best to be a decent person.... "I hope you all find peace and happiness." (abridged from urlLink his post on alt.suicide.holiday)

I am not about to turn my blog into an urlLink evangelizing platform, but the more I use Windows 95, the more I realize it was created by a bunch of programmers expecting it to be used by a bunch of programmers. And don't forget, this was in 1995, when the Internet was gaining popularity and home computers had been a fad for at least 10 years. Everyone who knows me knows I have a penchant for Apple Computers, and it's mostly because I was fortunate enough to be able to use one way, way back in 1985 at Microage in Moose Jaw. Look at that name: it's even before the age of intercaps. Anyway, the computer was completely unlike everything I knew about computers: stylish, innovative -- it had graphics! It had this little clicky-dooey called a mouse! And whatever you typed or drew on the screen came out looking exactly the same on the printer! Let's face it, it was a product that revolutionized an industry and literally changed the world. Enter Windows 95. Objectively, Windows 95 is little more than a cosmetic upgrade to Windows 3.1, which is barely tolerable. But putting aside all the philosophical problems I have with Windows 95, what set me off today was the alert boxes. I was working in Excel and re-opened the same spreadsheet I was working on. A box popped up telling me that if I chose to re-open the spreadsheet it would erase all my changes. That's all good and well -- I mean, I knew that already. But when I thought about the box the message came in, I was struck with exactly how unwieldy these messages are: they're crammed into this long, skinny box in the center of the screen, in a single colour, with nothing to differentiate the options you're expected to choose from. The box should be LARGE! Expansive, even. The text should be big, spaced out for comfortable reading; perhaps even positioned so the choices are more obvious. This is the type of alert dialog you get in the Mac OS. The Windows alert is what you get from a bunch of programmers creating for public consumption: the bare minimum. And at that, it feels like an afterthought -- you get the impression that they'd rather just have the screen flash, or have the computer beep with a "Y/N" option appearing. I mean, real programmers don't need that kind of instruction, therefore no one does. And looking a little deeper, this is typical of the kind of stuff you get from Microsoft in general: shoddy design, minimal effort, bells and whistles hyped to downplay the shortcomings. Windows 95 is hard to use and forces the user to adapt to its eccentricities. But I guess you can use anything as a hammer, if you need to. Now, detractors will tell me that Windows has come a long way since Windows 95: look at Windows 98, for instance, or Windows Me, Windows 2000, or Microsoft's latest and most dubious achievement, Windows XP. Yeah, all right, I concede. Windows has come a long way. But by the same token, typing monkies can eventually turn out Shakespeare, and I imagine it would be much easier if they had a good template to follow. Further, the idea of the GUI was invented in the 70's and has been stretched almost to its limit: there's not a lot of innovation left in that area. The question I wish to pose, though, is not about the similarities between Windows and the Mac OS, but why the public would adopt a ridiculous, unintuitive, backward product when a clearly better alternative already existed?

I finished Homebody on Saturday. Again, not at the level of Ender's Game, but it certainly did have some good parts to it. "When she moved into that room it would no longer be his. He would knock at the door if he wanted to speak to her. If she invited him in then he would go, but as a visitor. That was the way of it, for a builder like Don. You made beautiful spaces, you built with your whole heart, and then you invited someone else into the space you had made and gave them the keys and locked yourself out of it forever. I related a lot to the Don character in this novel, and not only because he was brooding and distant, and not because he was either afraid or unwilling to open himself to other people. We have a national-level event coming up in less than two weeks, and part of the work I do will be preparing the materials that go to the delegates. It's not quite the same as building a house, but it's still the basic kind of framework. One person will keep their materials in a shoebox on their bookshelf and revisit them from time to time, someone else will ditch the solid stuff and only keep the memories of the event: the places they visited, the people they met. Either way, this event will stay with these people for a long time, and I want it to be comfortable, and solid, and right to them, just as Don's houses were built to be homes. Now, a lot of this goes unfelt and unnoticed. The building contractors and engineers know if you've done a good job, and you yourself know where you've cut corners. But the average person doesn't see the creation process, doesn't see the late nights, the anxiety, the sweat, or the tears, they see only the finished product. It's hard, sometimes, knowing the amount of effort you've put into something, and knowing how it will never be fully appreciated. But we should try to appreciate it. We should slow down sometimes, pull ourselves back and try to see things in a different way. Ever notice how fluid our movements are sometimes? How your arms or legs or fingers just natually seem to be in the right spots at the right times? Tying your shoes is a delicious feat of dexterity, yet most adults perform it without a second thought. Remember how frustrating it was when you were three? How you would practice but you were all thumbs, and you would wear the uncomfortable shoes with the velcro straps so you wouldn't have laces to tie. Now, grown up, you do it unconsciously. Most people don't even think about the shoes they're tying until after they have them on. But at one point you chose your shoes carefully, focusing yourself tightly on the task, hoping that this would be the time you got it right. Reflect on the little things and the big things in your life. Remember the way things felt and contrast it with how things are now. Think about things in odd ways, ways that make you appreciate your thoughts, your actions, all the underlying effort that makes the world what it is. Think about 16 pennies to an inch. Think about ten billion pennies filling a football field every year. Think about the one who chose a particular font out of 2000 others and why, and think about the builder who fastened a nail three inches off-center so you could have a place to store your memories and live your life.

Besides, the only song I can play is Ol' Susanna, and while it's catchy, I don't think it's enough to get anyone off. You may find that a lot of people are concerned about their personal space. If you end up standing too close to them at the bus stop, say, or in an elevator, you'll either get people shying away in an effort to preserve their personal space, or they may become belligerent, forcing you out of it. I, however, am more concerned with my mental space. Whereas personal space is an area roughly a metre in radius from a person's body, mental space expands and contracts during the day depending on your location and the medium of information you're exposed to. Generally, your mental space is equal to the room you're occupying. Things like television and radio expand your mental space, as you're forced to interact with more people. If you're alone in your house, you are the only person in your mental space. If you're at a concert, sporting event, or something similar, your mental space is filled with hundred of other people. This is the crux of the mental space concept: while you can choose whether or not to allow people in your physical space, you can rarely choose to not have someone in your mental space. And just as some people don't like to be touched by strangers, there are people who don't like their mental space "invaded". But I believe that we are forced to develop a certain level of tolerance as we grow up, because our mental space will be filled daily with people we feel have no right to be there. It's just that some people will have more tolerance than others. As with many things, I find the battery metaphor very useful here. Imagine your tolerance level being the charge in a battery. As undesirable people come into your mental space, the charge decreases; if the charge gets to zero, or appreciably close, something bad happens -- you blow up, swear, become violent, burst into tears, or whatever. Essentially, you revert to some mode of protective behaviour that allows you to stop the drain of your battery in the quickest, most effective way. Then you begin recharging your battery, until the next draining episode. It's always about give and take, isn't it?

" urlLink It plays music on your crotch. " One of the more interesting quotes I've ever read. I may add this feature to my blog. Last night I went to a body building competition my friend Colin was entered in. It was an interesting event -- at four hours, it did drag on a bit, especially since you can only see so many guys flexing their abs before they all start to look the same -- but all the same, it was a very good time! One thing I found out is that body building is like any other sporting event. Spectators are encouraged to cheer on their favorites, and many of the competitors -- if not all of them -- feed off the crowd's enthusiasm. I felt bad for some of the people near the end of the show because it was obvious that the crowd was getting restless, and the level of excitement was waning. One guy walked off stage shaking his head as though he had not done as well as he expected. But it was just the crowd, guy! Just the crowd! If there's a lesson here, it's definitely not to judge yourself on other's opinions -- it's the adjudicators that matter, not the audience. I was people watching before the start of the show, and I commented on the level of narcissism present. I suppose that birds of a feather do flock together and all that, just like you'd expect few whites to show up at a black power rally, or few illiterates to be a poetry reading. Just the same, nearly all the men in the audience were huge and muscular, and a good part of the women were tall, skinny, bleach-blondes with big, fake boobs. Not that I have much of a problem with this, but my knee-jerk reaction is to equate this kind of behaviour with a level of insecurity -- are you really so displeased with your looks that you have to enact such radical changes? And must you date someone searching for the same kind of outward security? Isn't it truly the inside that matters, or are looks really all that's sufficient for some relationships? Are these people really happy, or are these relationships time-sensitive, being relegated to the garbage as the years pass? It's hard for me to say, but I'm a firm believer that personality trumps everything, and I have my doubts that the beauty of those people was anything more than skin deep. Once the competition started I found myself riding the energy level of the crowd. I was shocked at the level of support these people had for the competitors. It occurred to me that body building is the same kind of event as any other, but it's slightly more personal as you're not just putting your skill on display, but your body as well. By allowing yourself to be objectified in this manner you're opening your entire self up to inspection -- your level of training, your posing routine, and, inevitably, your body. A pianist, for instance, is not judged by how big his head is, or how much weight he carries; but body builders are judged on many fronts, leaving themselves open to a fuller defeat. It takes a special kind of person to get onto that stage, and I'm curious to know what it is that would drive a person to those lengths, and what it takes to psych themselves up. Several things did show clearly from this competition. One was the camaraderie of the competitors: it was friendship borne through war or intense competition, where they've all been through the same training, the same preparation, the same intensity. They had all shared the same experiences, and although there was no quarter given in the competition, there was a level of respect for each other that was never breached, even during the two unfortunate incidents when the crowd openly disagreed with the judging. This attitude came through especially strong during the pose-offs, where the competitors got a chance to expose their personalities and play off the crowd and each other. There was also a strong feeling of accomplishment present, even among the people who didn't win awards. All the competitors were proud of their work and their trials. This, for me, was the most satisfying part: knowing that, win or lose, the people present had achieved the goals they had set. When I talked with my friend Colin after the performance, he was glowing with happiness, and I was so very proud of what he accomplished. At 52, he was competing with many people less than half his age. In the Masters category (age 40+), he placed third of three; in the Middleweight category he had much stiffer competition, but much to my surprise and delight, managed a second place finish out of seven people. That was definitely the highlight of my evening. I think I learned a lot about body building by attending this event: it's not just a bunch of brainless, self-obsessed people showing off their bodies for their own satisfaction and the delight of people who enjoy watching these kinds of things. Rather, it's just as intense a level of training and competition as any other sport, and the people are as friendly and appreciative as anyone else. I don't think it's something I will find myself doing anytime soon, but Colin waited until his fifties -- I have plenty of time to change my mind.

When you're young, it's important to have The Day Off for your birthday: you're a special person, this is your special day, and you shouldn't be required to do chores, let's say, or homework, or go to school. There's a game show on the urlLink Game Show Network called urlLink Friend or Foe , which I believe to be the most insipid game show in television history -- and this includes all those game show parodies you see on urlLink SNL and urlLink MadTV , and those weird ones from other countries, too. The show pairs two strangers who attempt to answer trivia questions, gaining money for each correct answer. At one point in the game the players go to what they call the "Trust Box", and are asked to choose either Friend or Foe. If they both choose Friend, the players split the money; if one chooses Friend and the other chooses Foe, the player who chose Foe gets all the money; if both players choose Foe, neither gets any money. Looking at things probabilistically, there are four possible combinations of answers, each with an equal probability of .5: Friend/Friend, Friend/Foe, Foe/Friend, and Foe/Foe. Let's suppose you choose Friend. Let's also assume that the total value of the money is 1, and that a portion of the money can be represented by a decimal (50% = .5, etc.). There is a 50% chance that your opponent chose Friend and a 50% chance that they chose Foe. If your opponent also chose Friend, you get half the money; if your opponent chose Foe, you get nothing. This makes your expected value for Friend: 50% x Half the money + 50% x None of the money, or (.5)(.5)+(.5)(0), or .25. Now let's suppose you choose Foe. Again, there is a 50% chance that your opponent chose Friend and a 50% chance that they chose Foe. If your opponent chose Friend, you get all the money; if your opponent chose Foe, you both get nothing. This makes your expected value for Foe: 50% x All of the money + 50% x None of the money, or (.5)(1) + (.5)(0), or .5. What all this means is that in the long term you are expected to receive about 25% of the money if you choose Friend each time, and 50% of the money if you choose Foe. It doesn't take a rocket surgeon to see that there is a distinct advantage to taking Foe. What sets this game apart, though, is the point where you try and convince your opponent to choose Friend. A typical exchange goes something like this: "Opponent, we played really well together during the rounds, and we deserve to both leave winners. So let's both choose Friend and split the money." "Opponent, I agree with you, and as you know from my ridiculous financial statement -- which they shamelessly aired to discourage participation -- I need money like Pigpen needs a bath. I wouldn't be here without you, so let's choose Friend!" I argue that a better exchange would be like this: "Look Opponent, this game is fixed. Based on the math, it's definitely to your advantage to take Foe every time. But knowing this means I know you'll take Foe -- forcing me to also take Foe, and leaving us both penniless. I came on this show to win something, and I think it's better for both of us to leave as winners than as losers. Vote Friend and let's share the loot." Having calmly explained that you understand the metagame and there's no way he can with without choosing Friend, you then have to mercilessly backstab your opponent by choosing Foe. You have to choose Foe every time, regardless of the impassioned speech you gave. Friend leaves you playing the patsy to your opponent's unscrupulous behaviour. Foe leaves you looking like an untrusting asshole. It's an insipid show with a terrible premise and a talentless host. Game shows are supposed to be fun , for Christ's sake -- let's keep it fun and let everyone walk away a winner. (Please see this urlLink Wikipedia entry for more information on expected value.)

Way, way back, when I was in university, I was in a deep, deep funk. Funky enough to want my life to just abruptly end, but not quite funky enough to take the necessary steps. Life was simply one weight followed by another, and another, day after day, never letting up. And I was so very tired of it. Eventually, on the advice of a friend, I went to Student Health to see someone. I remember sitting in the waiting room looking at posters produced by drug companies, and thinking that some drug would be prescribed to me, and how the doctors were paid by the companies to foist these drugs on people, and how much of an assembly line it was: ailment-drug, ailment-drug, ailment-drug. I wasn't feeling particularly down that day, or nervous, or uncomfortable. I was finally called into the examination room and the doctor, a wonderful woman in her mid-thirties, asked me what was wrong. And in response, I inexplicably burst into tears. I remember how much I ached as it passed through me; I had never known how I really felt, what I had locked away inside, until that very moment when it all just tumbled out like a tangle of drunken gymnasts. I'm often reminded of the Zen saying, "When the student is ready, the teacher will appear"; I think I was just waiting for the right person to ask me how they could help. I apologized for my outburst, and after some talking she put me on Paxil, the first of my on-again/off-again romance with antidepressants. There are a few other things that I took away from my visits with this delightful woman who changed my life: she told me that, oftentimes, people on antidepressants feel "more like themselves"; I've found that it's very hit-and-miss. She also told me to read urlLink The Celestine Prophesy and Stephen King's urlLink Insomnia , as "those guys really seem to know something the rest of us don't." And this, I think, she was right about.
I lost my job today. It was a great six years, by and large -- definitely more good times than bad. I don't know if I can ask for much more than that. Sorry, everyone.

I received yet another hit to my blog by someone looking for information on The Bannock Shack. So, to facilitate this continued search for information, I present to you Deron's Official Bannock Shack Post. The Bannock Shack can be contacted at: The Bannock Shack 3115 5th Ave. Regina, SK S4T 7T2 Phone: (306) 522-7240 It's exact location can be found urlLink here . (I normally use urlLink MapBlast for my mapping needs, but it choked on the address. Stupid Microsoft.) If you're coming south on Albert Street, you'll find a Tim Horton's on your right side and a Petcetera on your left. Avoid the temptation to eat at Tim Horton's! If you're Vietnamese, avoid the temptation to eat at Petcetera! Instead, go one block further south and turn to your right. If you're coming north on Albert Street and you get to the Tim Horton's/Petcetera intersection, you've gone one block too far. I wish I could tell you where to turn, but the landmarks escape me. "But Deron," I hear you ask, "how's the food?" Well, I'm no expert on aboriginal cuisine, but I think it's pretty good. They offer a good array of food, ranging from traditional North American stuff like burgers, fries, and pizza, to things like buffalo burgers and Indian tacos. The burgers, of course, come on a piece of fried bannock instead of a bun. They also serve the popular "bullets and bannock" -- some kind of meatball and potato soup, which I think is delicious, and you can get the 6-pack or 12-pack of fried bannock to go. You can even get breakfast in the mornings, with a good plate bacon and eggs for $2.99. But don't ask me why the Toonie Sandwich costs $2.50, because I don't know. I've had buffalo at urlLink Wanuskewin , but I haven't tried the buffalo burger at The Bannock Shack. Similarly, I've had Indian tacos at urlLink Junior Nationals in urlLink Yorkton , but not at The Bannock Shack. I have had the Bannock Burger and fries, which was pretty good. I've had a lot of fried bannock, which is very good, but kind of greasy. Nothing out of the ordinary, though, that's just how it's prepared. I'm a big fan of the Bullets and Bannock, and get it practically every time I'm there. I've also had their pizza, but I think it's the weakest food they offer. It was big and thick, like urlLink Vern's Pizza , but very greasy -- so much so that we had grease dripping down our hands as we ate. Overall, I recommend The Bannock Shack, and not just because it's awesome to have a restaurant serving aboriginal food. The food there is delicious, the prices are very reasonable, and the atmosphere is terrific. Now when people search for urlLink The Bannock Shack on Google, maybe they'll find what they're looking for. Please note that I am not affiliated with The Bannock Shack, I'm just a white guy who likes to eat there.
